snippet.textDisplay: Hi Hannah. I know you’re going through a lot of pain right now and you’re right these are shitty feelings and they suck... Speaking as a person who has had to live her life without a father (divorced parents; left and made another family) I know how crushing this feeling is to be forsaken, to be rejected, to be alienated. I want to tell you that this is not your fault (you already knew that of course) and you have NOTHING to be ashamed of. If he can’t see past his fealty for a religion that’s clearly damaging and controlling and twisted that’s no one’s fault but his own. It is truly a shame that he’s too wrapped up in this cult of his to be able to share a life and have a relationship with you. You’re not any less or any less deserving of love because of the ties he’s made. Take as much time as you need to process this hurt and to let come and go, and by the time you’ve healed I hope it’s in time for your beautiful wedding day because you deserve to be happy with Ella, especially on that day of celebration with other loved ones are you. 💕 There are people who love you and Ella and are excited to see y’all together down at the aisle, it’s going to be an exciting and beautiful time, and you should be able to experience that beautiful day without anyone bringing you down. It’s going to be spectacular. It is truly his loss and he’s going to miss out on seeing his beautiful daughter in an exciting and important part of her life, but you know what fuck it. It’s your life Hannah. You deserve to be happy and deserve much better than this hollowness he is presenting you with. I’m sending you all the love and positive vibes.

snippet.textDisplay: I can't say I understand completely, but I definitely understand the situation and have experienced something similar. There's already too much antisemitism in the world and I don't want to add fuel to the fire so here's a disclaimer: I am Jewish because I want to be, because I like the religion and find beauty in it. I chose to go through the process of converting for the sake of marrying my fiancee. It was excruciating and made my family feel like I was abandoning them for a family that didn't accept me as I was. I can handle his family not liking me, I almost expect that regardless of who I date (not that I'm unlikable, just because I'm insecure). What I found hard, was the feeling that my partner might have chose his family over our love if I didn't officially convert. That it's "unconditional love" on the condition that I'm Jewish. Since converting, I have strayed from the religion, for many reasons, and wonder if I'm disappointing him. I feel like a fraud, that I scammed him into loving my under the pretense that I would be religious and will he still love me if I'm not? We have been together for 9 years and we are getting married in a few months and I know that he truly loves me and that we're soulmates. But it's still something I struggle with internally, asking myself if I would be enough, or if he would still choose me if I decided not to convert. Would his family be upset but eventually come around to it or would we have to elope because we don't have the support of his family to have a wedding, or even want to attend our ceremony. Knowing that they were against us dating for so many years has made me feel uncomfortable to be around them even if they now welcome me with open arms after the conversion. Being from the outside, secular world, looking in, it absolutely seems like a cult as do all religions at this point. I feel your pain because it's something I've been dealing with for over 9 years... and while it may not be to the extent of what you're going through, I am here to tell you that your feelings are valid. Your pain is justified, even if you saw it coming a mile away, it hurts to be less important than religion (or a cult). Your family should want to celebrate your happiness even if it doesn't agree with their ideology.. In fact, just the fact that you are happy should be enough to change their ideology. You are worthy of all the love and happiness and I'm so sorry that you have to deal with this. I wish you nothing but the best and that you are able to resolve this, whatever that may mean. You are loved and you don't need their validation to know that, even if you want it. He's an idiot if he's choosing to miss out on your life and the love you could have if he let you in. From the bottom of my heart, I'm sorry.

snippet.textDisplay: I understand how much this must hurt and I by no means am on your dads side. I’m so sorry for this. I am very sorry that you have to go through this! I just hope you can understand that your dad believes in something that seems very real to him in his eyes, encouraging something that he thinks is against gods law is very hard for him too. I know you are hurting but don’t give up on your dad. Love him the way you want to be loved. Love can overcome anything and everything❤️ and congrats on your engagement and marriage. Love and happiness to you!

snippet.textDisplay:
It’s like when a parent chooses drugs over you. You can still love them deeply, but it’s better for you to walk away, because they will not change unless they choose you.
Don’t expose yourself to this person. Mourn the person you wish he was, and let that person/relationship die. He will only be a source of pain in your life, and it’s better to feel the grief with no more contact. Because grief starts to dull over the years. But contact brings fresh pain.
Take care of yourself my dear!

snippet.textDisplay: I'm a pastor (not JW).  I have a friend who just got married and whose parents didn't attend for the same reasons.  It's something that I will never understand.  My friends' story, your story and everyone like it breaks my heart over and over again.  I wish there was something I could say to you and everyone watching that would make it better....but there isn't.  The best I have is that God is grieving with you.  And that you're created in the image of that God...the whole of you.  You're loved by many, but children need the love of their parents and that pain is real and should be honored.

snippet.textDisplay: For me, it was alcohol. My dad continually and consistently chose alcohol over me. One day I actually had to sit him down and make him say it aloud. I said it's either have me in your life, and stay here (he was living with me at the time), or continue to drink, and but you can't be here and I can't let you be in my life because it's harmful to me. And he got up and got his stuff and left. I called 911 and reported him as a drunk driver, as that's what he was at that moment. And that was it. It hurt, and still hurts, that I wasn't important enough to my parent for him to choose me. But it does get more easy to tolerate as time goes by. I hope you don't continue to let him stay in your life and harm you the way he seems to be doing.
snippet.textOriginal: For me, it was alcohol. My dad continually and consistently chose alcohol over me. One day I actually had to sit him down and make him say it aloud. I said it's either have me in your life, and stay here (he was living with me at the time), or continue to drink, and but you can't be here and I can't let you be in my life because it's harmful to me. And he got up and got his stuff and left. I called 911 and reported him as a drunk driver, as that's what he was at that moment. And that was it. It hurt, and still hurts, that I wasn't important enough to my parent for him to choose me. But it does get more easy to tolerate as time goes by. I hope you don't continue to let him stay in your life and harm you the way he seems to be doing.

snippet.textDisplay: I hope all these tens of thousands of people, and millions more who will never see this video, are able to take a tiny part of the hurt and sadness you're dealing with from your heart. snippet.textDisplay:
As a practicing Christian— I am here to say my heart is breaking for you. I’m happy that this video is a good means of allowing us to grieve with you and you to open up to your platform, because that is how we are designed as humans, to be in community. Also that your love for your Dad, even after your clear and intense hurt, is so beautiful. This world is so so broken, and on our days that we feel so hurt from our own family members, it points to something so much greater than our understanding. The lenses that we each look at this work through are different and always have bias, your father has a lens, you have a lens, JWs have their lenses, and even science has lenses that distorts our opinions. It’s hard to see but, our hearts are designed for love from a father, and this video brings so much light to that. God will never forsake you, and this breaks his heart more than it breaks yours. That’s such good news... because not only does that not put so much pressure on any human to make no mistakes (ie: our families) but it also gives you so much fulfillment in the darkest moments of life. Because you are heard and each one of us uniquely made for a purpose and life chain of events. You don’t need to be perfect, life will be hard and you can find happiness outside of your fathers opinions.

My DMs are open for questions, a listening ear, and ridicule :)
IG @feliciamemos

snippet.textDisplay:
I want to take a moment to say thank you. I have followed your journey for years now. Watching you struggle with accepting your sexuality, finding love, heartbreak, and all the normal ups and down. Through it all you have still taken the time and effort to entertain and to teach. To bring joy and information to people. To support everyone who reaches out. I have watched your platform grow into a thing that has actually changed the world, and made corners of it better and safer.

I am so proud of you. I can only imagine how difficult this whole journey has been. I have been struggling with my relationship with my mother. This video has given me perspective that I really needed. Thank you.

Thank you for your vulnerability. Thank you for sharing your struggles and your triumphs. Thank you for sharing the heart of Hart. I am ever thankful and grateful for your presence in the world. And I am ecstatic about your adventures and so excited for the life that you get to lead in love with Ella.

Thank you. Because of you, I choose reckless optimism, even when things are at their hardest.

snippet.textDisplay: You have Nothing to be ashamed of. Sometimes people don't understand concepts such as love.
